results.title: The Four seasons of Japan
results.brief_description: Japanese countryside seen during the four seasons of the year. Eaqch season is marked by definite changes in the appearance of the landscape and foliage and each is celebrated by an appropriate festival.Shows changes in everyday life, sports and customs, and in nature, through each season.

results.title: The Four seasons
results.brief_description: World famous Maestro, Lorin Maazel and soloists of the National Orchestra of France perform Vivaldi’s baroque masterpiece, “The Four Seasons”. Each concerto describes a different season and the music is brought alive in colour panoramas of four great cities: Paris in Spring, New York in Summer, Venice in Autumn, Moscow in Winter. Rating: G

results.title: The Four Minute Mile
results.brief_description: An on-the-spot account of Roger Bannister’s record-breaking mile, run on the Oxford University Athletic Ground. Shows the brilliant performance of Chataway and Brasher as pace-makers. The film concludes with a brief camera interview with Bannister

results.title: The Fountains of Bernini
results.creator_credit: Centre for Mass Communication, Columbia University, Paul Buckhurst and Robert Hillmann
results.brief_description: Takes a look at some of the most important fountains in the history of western art and the life of the genius who created them. The atmosphere of the Baroque Age and Bernini’s own religious, political and aesthetic ideas are conveyed visually as well as through music and narration. Narrated by Steven Gilburn.

results.title: The Fountainhead
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Henry Blanke and King Vidor
results.brief_description: Adapted from the 1943 novel by Ayn Rand, this film focuses on a four-cornered conflict of egoism between architect Roark (inspired by Frank Lloyd Wright), a newspaper magnate, his daughter, and an opposed, socialistically inclined architecture critic. The combination of Rand’s one-dimensionally didactic dialogue, Vidor’s engagement with the theme of the spirituality of creativity, his proclivity for soaring love-hate sexuality, and an architectural vision in the design, make this a deliriously extreme celebration of individualism in American cinema. Cast includes Gary Cooper, Patricia Neal, Raymond Massey, Kent Smith and Robert Douglas.

results.title: The Fountain of Jabalia
results.creator_credit: United Nations Films and Jose Quisand
results.brief_description: Depicts the life of Palesinian Arab refugees at Jabalia Camp, in the Gaza Strip. The film shows the work of the vocational training schools which are producing skilled craftsmen whose services are in keen demand. It also illistrates how the United Nations is setting up families in their own farms so that they can become self supporting.

results.title: The Foundling
results.brief_description: Based on a book of the same name by Carol Carrick, and a sequel to “The Accident”. “The Foundling” begins several months after Chris’ dog, Bodger, has been run over and killed. Chris’ father takes him to the local animal shelter to pick out a dog to keep, but Chris feels he would be betraying Bodger. Before long a neighbour tells Chris of a stray pup seen in the area and without hesitation he undertakes a search for the missing animal.

results.title: The Foundations of wealth. Part 1. How it all began
results.brief_description: Uses animation and docuemtary footage to establish the concept of living at subsistence level. Shows how vulnerable people are when they need to consume everything they produce in order to survive and points towards the concept of creating a surplus. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: The Fortune in the forests
results.brief_description: Portrays the Swedish lumber industry, which in the 1950’s played a vital part in Sweden’s economy. Near the end of winter, power saws fell thousands of trees. The logs are hauled by tractor to the nearest river bank. In spring the logs are bulldozed into the melting rivers, and commence their journey in the fast flowing waters to the timbermills which cluster around the river mouths. Here they are sorted and graded by skilled lumberjacks, hauled into mills, and cut into timber for an endless variety of uses. In Sweden trees are a crop, and care is taken to prevent bushfires and indiscriminate felling. The forests of Sweden are a heritage from the past-they must be replanted and guarded from danger so that they may continue to be a source of wealth to future generations. Story by Albert Viksen; photographed by Sven Olsson; narrated by Burnett Anderson.

results.title: The Forsyte saga. - Vol. 12: Episodes 24-26
results.brief_description: While Michael busies himself with promoting a slum-clearance scheme, Fleur’s restlessness is further stirred by repeated meetings with Jon… not all of them by chance. Even Soames is persuaded to join Michael’s scheme, and Fleur seeks to quell her growing discontent by opening a rest home for factory girls. But, like Fleur, the past will not rest.” Nothing really changes,” she tells Jon.
